Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I stared at my screen, heart pounding as new bug reports kept popping up in our team chat. Users were getting kicked out of the app at random, and QA was tagging me directly, asking for urgent fixes. My manager’s message was clear: “We need this stable before tomorrow.” I knew how much our clients depended on us, and I felt the weight of their frustration. But as I glanced at the clock, my stomach twisted. The polling station would close in less than two hours, and I still had to get across town. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss voting this year, not after all the debates and discussions. My civic duty felt just as important as my job. But if I left now, I’d let my team down; if I stayed, I might lose my chance to have a say in the election. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I sat frozen, torn between the demands of my work and my responsibility as a citizen.
